fields.description:
Although the source repository alias is mapped to a Bamboo user...

!http://content.screencast.com/users/FelipeKraemer/folders/Jing/media/c84e2d55-3132-473b-9684-b397365a8f1b/00000033.png!

... the dashboard sometimes shows the the source repository alias instead of the user name:
!http://content.screencast.com/users/FelipeKraemer/folders/Jing/media/95cd1617-eaa7-42d7-9293-f4ef1728470f/00000034.png!

See "Changes by *atl*" in the second plan.
fields.summary: Dashboard showing source repository alias instead of the user name

fields.description: Only the top level cache directories (the one with random names) are created by Bamboo. All subrepos are created by Mercurial and Bamboo has no control over them.
fields.summary: Allow configuring the top level cache directory names for HG in order to make the caching to work for sub-repos with repative paths.

fields.description:
It is great that bamboo can drop branches after a period of inactivity

but it would be yet better if there could be actions taken to do further cleanup when a branch is expired

(for example to remove feature-branch staging deployments or transition related JIRA tickets)
fields.summary: Allow tasks to be done at branch cleanup time

fields.description:
Most of our agents are powerful enough to run several jobs in parallel.
Installing 4 agents on the same machine is not a solution when the checkouts are GB size. This means well need to buy 4 time bigger HDD if we run 4 agents on the same machine...
fields.summary: Allow to build more then 1 job on the agent
Provide metrics for active agents

fields.summary: Error displayed on Build Summary screen when correlating Deployment Plan has reference to Deleted Release

fields.description:
The svnkit that comes with 5.1 doesn't support svn 1.8. The repository cannot be checked out in the build process. Since 1.8 has many important features, and all our repositories are updated, we can't incorporate bamboo right now.

The latest svnkit, supports 1.8.
fields.summary: Add support for Subversion 1.8 workspace

fields.description:
Config plan -> Branches -> Create branch -> Create branch manually.

You need to manually position the cursor with the mouse to start typing (tab doesn't focus it either)
fields.summary: Autofocus in input box when creating a new branch manually

fields.description:
Some customers would like to turn on all local agents at night when they're not worried about license contention for the tools they are using in their jobs. 
They would like to disable some of those agents during the day.

Currently it is only possible to [enable / disable them manually|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Disabling+or+deleting+an+agent]. It would be nice if the agents could be automatically enabled / disabled based on the time of the day.
fields.summary: Allow enabling / disabling agents based on the time of the day

fields.description:
Our release process is such that in the begining of a release cycle, the release vehicle (aka release version number) is undetermined. A temporary codename is used as the release version.

As we get closer to Feature freeze, the official version is finalized and we need to update the build plan from it's code version to the official version.

There is a functionality in bamboo to "move" the build plan from one version to another version. However, as part of this move, changelist info on the build summary page , since last build before rename,  seems to be lost.

We use  perforce as our source code repository.  It will be great if there's a way to rename build plan version without incuring missing changelists in the 1st build after the switch.

Steps to replicate the issue:

1. Administration>Plans>move plans
2. Destination Project: New Project
         Project Name: <enter new project name>
         Project Key: <enter new project key>
3. Check the plan to move
4. click 'move' button
5. provide new name and key
6. click 'done'.
7. Run the new plan.
8. Build summary does not list out the changelists since the last change.
fields.summary: Code change information missing after plan is 'moved'

fields.description:
In Bamboo Cloud there is no way in the UI to delete a project.

The workaround is to issue a {{DELETE}} to {{/builds/rest/capabilities/aggregate-root/bamboo.project/FOO}} where FOO is the project key.
fields.summary: Allow for projects to be deleted

fields.description:
I have set up stash to use the "feature branch" workflow.
Bamboo is triggered anytime a dev pushes commits to his/her branch. When the branch plan is finished, stash doesn't receive a build status update.
If I build the master branch (by running the plan or pushing to master), stash receive the build status update.
As a consequence, no pull request can be merge to master because i use the "at least one build succeed" enforcement.

I am sure that stash doesn't receive the update in the branch case but does in the default case, see the attached log.

It sounds like a bug to me, or maybe i'm missinng something.

Bamboo: version 5.1.1 build 3902 - 12 Sep 13
Stash: 2.8.1
fields.summary: No build status update to Stash when Bamboo build a branch plan

fields.description:
While the out-of-box EBS image configurations are quite useful, it would be nice to have full integration and management of creating new ones inside of Bamboo itself.  This includes tools like Ansible, Puppet, and Chef.

The idea would be to have a "Create Image" button that lets you start with one of the out-of-box configurations and creates the image for you by uploading a script/manifest/etc.  If the out-of-box configuration changes, Bamboo could (optionally) recreate the image by re-running the previously upload script/manifest/etc.
fields.summary: Provide a way to build new elastic images with Chef, Puppet or Ansible

fields.description: I'd like to be able to clone an existing local agent. This would help set up multiple local agents with the exact same capabilities.
fields.summary: Clone agent

fields.description: I'd like to be able to edit multiple agents properties in one edit. This feature should be similar to bulk editing plans. For example, it would be nice to be able to edit a capability of 5 local agents in one operation.
fields.summary: Bulk edit local and/or remote agents

fields.description:
I attempted to install the new standalone version of Bamboo 5.1.1 with Tomcat baked in, but it didn't seem to want to handle my reverse proxy and Apache HTTP Server https setup. So, I downloaded the WAR version instead. Please continue providing the WAR file until it's clear that all the various interesting ways people set up their Bamboo instances will work with the standalone version with Tomcat baked in.

Thanks! and keep up the good work!
fields.summary: Problems installing new standalone Tomcat instance of Bamboo 5.1.1

fields.description:
currently, when we spawn a background process in a job, the job won't terminate. This is not desirable in several valid use cases.
We also have cases when a foreground process blocks build.
fields.summary: Investigate spawning of processes on Windows

fields.description: The Bash shell scripts that start and stop Bamboo in the Linux standalone version that is now standard, to not contain the "#!/bin/bash" line that would allow them to be executed according to the instructions (from the shell).
fields.summary: Standalone start/stop scripts for Linux don't include sha-bang (#!)

fields.description:
On Windows, Bamboo Agent will fail when trying to do a clean build on a source directory which contains broken NTFS junctions.

For example, our binaries are put into a subdirectory of our main source code tree. For example:

build-dir/JOB1/SourceCode/build-artifacts

During the build process, relative NTFS junctions are created within build-artifacts, pointing to other locations within SourceCode:

build-artifacts/directory1 ---> ../ParentDirectory1
build-artifacts/directory2 ---> ../ParentDirectory2

When Bamboo agent tries to clean the build directory, it first deletes ParentDirectory1 and ParentDirectory2, breaking the junctions.

Then when the directory-walking code tries to access build-artifacts/directory1, it fails. This throws an exception and the cleaning process fails. Subsequently the entire build fails.

Code should be fixed to detect broken junctions and delete them without trying to walk further down in the hierarchy.

NOTE: We use Bamboo OnDemand. Currently at version 5.2
fields.summary: On Windows, Elastic Bamboo Agent cannot clean source directory containing NTFS junctions

fields.summary: Application link creation screen does not scroll

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
Administrator is unable to set the "Cache refresh interval" to zero in Bamboo User repository settings when they want to integrate the user of Crowd or JIRA to Bamboo. This is quite important as some of the users might get assigned to Bamboo but due to the cache, it need specific time before the user data get loaded into cache.

From [this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Crowd], it should be configurable to zero. However if you configure from the Administration panel, it will return "Cache refresh interval must be a positive integer." error message and it will be like the following.
!userrepo-bug.png!

*Steps to replicate*
# Have a Bamboo and Crowd server running
# From Bamboo, go to _Administration >> User Repositories_
# Integrate to Crowd using the configured Application server in Crowd
# Set the _Cache refresh interval_ to zero

*Workaround*
You could change the cache configuration through {{crowd.properties}} file in {{$BAMBOO-HOME/xml-data/configuration}} directory. The parameter would be.
{noformat}
bamboo.crowd.cache.minutes
{noformat}
fields.summary: Unable to set "Cache refresh interval" to zero in Bamboo user repository setting

fields.description:
The Thoughtworks product Go has a great layout of build status as it pertains to the deployment pipeline:

http://i.stack.imgur.com/pkYfs.jpg

If Bamboo could provide this kind of visualization (similar to the Wallboard, or available through the UI), that would be very useful. Bonus points if deployments could happen via "Drag and Drop" from an artifact list.
fields.summary: Visualize deployments

fields.description:
- I installed the the stand-alone (download) edition of Bamboo 5.1.1 (64 bit) for Windows.
- I configured Java (JDK 1.7.0_40) and the environment variables as stated in the Installation Guide for Windows.
- I then chose the "express" installation and configuration (for demo/evaluation purposes only).
- Creating the first project/plan, I try to add a MSBuild task (after a mercurial source repository checkout task). The screen displays a "Working sub directory" field on the right hand side of the window specifying the folder/directory where to find the solution/project/msbuild xml file in relation to the source repository working directory. But when I click the context-sensitive help button (image of a question mark next to the field) opens up a new browser tab/window that tells me the page/content I'm looking for does not exist (Page not found).

This is not a serious bug, but it could be rather annoying to clueless users (like me :)) who really want to learn more about how "working sub directories" work but cannot find the info without doing some online searching.

Thanks
fields.summary: Context Sensitive Help Missing For Working Sub Directory for MSBuild task

fields.description: When Bamboo is running on https and try to load icons using the URL localhost:51235/icon, warnings are thrown. This is mainly due to mixed content warning where we try to load an insecure content on https. This is similar to https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-3538 , https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-2602 and https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/AOD-3960
fields.summary: Bamboo is trying to load an icon from localhost:51235

fields.description:
What exactly happens? There is a typical task: *Checkout from Git*. This task now fails (!) *{{git}}* fails to checkout to specified custom revision (we use custom builds for deploying custom revisions on sandbox servers).

*{{git}}* complains on following:
{code}
simple	23-Sep-2013 09:04:58	Checking out revision 89d771a.
simple	23-Sep-2013 09:04:58	error: pathspec '89d771a' did not match any file(s) known to git.
error	23-Sep-2013 09:04:58	Checkout to revision 89d771a has failed.
simple	23-Sep-2013 09:04:58	Warning: failed to checkout source code to directory '/home/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/MRS-WEBSITE4-DISTR/re
{code}

As you can see, *git* does not see {{89d771a}} to be a valid commit.
fields.summary: Custom build functionality is broken in Bamboo 5.x

fields.description:
I'm on Atlassian Bamboo version 4.4.5 build 3507 - 27 Mar 13

I'd like the posibility to break up a build plan as follows:

- run mvn clean install on each commit

- run mvn clean install sonar:sonar nightly at 1am

Currently this cannot be down without script hacks or breaking it up into separate Build Plans which aren't good options
fields.summary: Add ability to schedule a task within a Build Plan

fields.description:
I have a set of Deployment Tasks defined in this order:

# Clean Working Directory
# Source Code Checkout A
# Source Code Checkout B

*Expected*
# The working dir is cleaned.  
# A is checked out
# B is checked out

*Actual*
# The working dir is cleaned
# A is checked out
# The working dir is cleaned (again)
# B is checked out

(No, Force Clean Build is not checked on either of the Source Checkout tasks.)

Here are some example logs.
(The build in question is: https://extranet-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/deploy/config/configureEnvironmentTasks.action?environmentId=472121346)

fields.description:
Here are the steps to reproduce the misbehavior:
- Add a branch plan based on an SVN branch
- Configure that repository triggers the build
- Commit a change to that repository branch and see that the branch gets queued up
- By the time the previous build is running, commit another change. It's supposed to trigger the build again, and the build should get queued up. Every next commit should be queued up, but Bamboo doesn't detect the changes:
{code}
2013-09-30 09:38:19,731 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-1] [DashboardCachingManagerImpl] Plan cache updated for 1 plans in 0:00:00.076
2013-09-30 09:38:19,732 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-13] [DependencyChainListener] Checking children plans of [PROJ1-SVNT0] for plan PROJ1-SVNT0-8
2013-09-30 09:38:19,734 INFO [AtlassianEvent::0-BAM::EVENTS:pool-2-thread-13] [DependencyChainListener] Finished checking children plans of 'Project-1 - SVNTest - epicenter-2.0-branch' for plan PROJ1-SVNT0-8
2013-09-30 09:38:21,714 INFO [qtp901833818-567] [AccessLogFilter] 127.0.0.1 GET http://localhost:8085/bamboo/api/rest/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=PROJ1-SVNT 179739kb
2013-09-30 09:38:21,741 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-4] [SvnRepository] Collecting changes for 'PROJ1-SVNT0' on path 'file:///Users/akhachatryan/dev/Repositories/SVNCustomer/SVNTest/branches/epicenter-2.0-branch' from version 6338 to -1
2013-09-30 09:38:21,741 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-1] [SvnRepository] Collecting changes for 'PROJ1-SVNT2' on path 'file:///Users/akhachatryan/dev/Repositories/SVNCustomer/SVNTest/branches/epicenter-1.3-new-ui' from version 6338 to -1
2013-09-30 09:38:21,741 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-2] [SvnRepository] Collecting changes for 'PROJ1-SVNT1' on path 'file:///Users/akhachatryan/dev/Repositories/SVNCustomer/SVNTest/branches/epicenter-2.1-branch' from version 6338 to -1
2013-09-30 09:38:21,746 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-1] [ChangeDetectionListenerAction] No changes found for 'PROJ1-SVNT2'
2013-09-30 09:38:21,746 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-2] [ChangeDetectionListenerAction] No changes found for 'PROJ1-SVNT1'
2013-09-30 09:38:21,746 INFO [4-BAM::PlanExec:pool-7-thread-4] [ChangeDetectionListenerAction] No changes found for 'PROJ1-SVNT0'
{code}
For the trunk, it doesn't update the build queue immediately, but after some time the builds appear. 

This is the configuration in the post-commit SVN hook:
{code}
/Users/akhachatryan/Atlassian/Bamboo4.4.5/atlassian-bamboo-4.4.5/scripts/svn-triggers/postCommitBuildTrigger.sh http://localhost:8085/bamboo PROJ1-SVNT
{code}

This is the content of the postcommitBuildTrigger file:
{code}
#!/bin/bash

# the base url of the bamboo server
#baseurl="$1/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey="
baseurl="$1/api/rest/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey="

#
# Use the REST API to trigger a build
#

# Moves to the 2nd param (first is URL)
shift
# Loop for each build key
while (( "$#" )); do

   #
   # Invoke the trigger
   #
   remoteCall=$baseurl$1
   echo "Detected last directory that was committed ... triggering $remoteCall"
   /usr/local/bin/wget --timeout=10 -t1 $remoteCall -O /dev/null

   shift
done


exit 0
{code}

fields.description:
Hi,

While continuously using bamboo for the last year or so I noticed a few features that I would be very happy to see in the next release, which would make the life of bamboo administrators much easier:

1. On the Administration -> Agents screen put a small indicator regarding the disk free status of the host (green, yellow, red). I know this information is present in the host info, but if you have a lot of hosts you have to do a lot of clicks.
2. When there is a scheduled maintenance of bamboo it would be great if there would be a "placeholder" screen instead of Error 503 (telling there is a maintenance with a message from the administrator) ... Also, there should be the possibility to initiate maintenance from the bamboo admin screen, which would send a mail to everyone participating in the bamboo ecosystem.

Regards
fields.summary: Feature Request for Bamboo

fields.description:
The feature that rolls up the summary of Jira tickets in a given build in Bamboo is great but it's not really that useful to us because we do multiple builds to our development environment before sending a build to QA.

What would be awesome is if Bamboo could roll up included Jira tickets based on the difference between the last deploy to a particular environment and the current deploy. That way if there were builds in between, the issues from them could be indicated in the specific environment release.

I know you can go into a release and manually get the ticket differences by specifying the former release version. Automatically having a link to those differences between the current deployment project and builds currently installed per environment somewhere in the deploy pages would be awesome.
fields.summary: Bamboo Jira issues rolled up by release to environment instead of build

fields.description:
The bamboo.sh was deprecated in version 5.0 and onwards.  There are now two scripts - /bin/start-bamboo.sh and /bin/stop-bamboo.sh

This causes an issue.  We used to link to the bamboo.sh script to /etc/init.d/bamboo and could pass the start parameter (and also stop, restart, status). 

Separate scripts does away with the status functionality, and makes it more difficult to automate bamboo start/stop with server stop and start issues.

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
When we link JIRA and Bamboo, you could show the list of issues from JIRA in Bamboo _Issues_ tab in Build summary. You could see how many issues are related to this build. You could it either by commenting on the build summary, on the commit message or link it manually. However if one of the issues are deleted in JIRA, it will render the whole issues list wrongly with message _Could not obtain issue details from JIRA_. Look at the screenshot below for example.
!jirabamboobug-issues.png!

*Steps to replicate*
# Startup JIRA and Bamboo
# Link them up through _Administration >> Application Link_
# Make sure the link work perfectly (you could comment issue key in build summary and check on the _Issues_ tab if it's listed down
# Put few more JIRA issues to be linked to this particular Bamboo build
# Delete one of the issue
# Notice all Issues will have _Could not obtain issue details from JIRA_ message

fields.description:
Hey Atlassians!

You can see the contents of masked variables (the ones with "password" in their key) when you click on "Add variable to version" in release versioning configuration screen for deployment project.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a global variable with key: "testpassword" and value "abc". Normally, this variable is masked and you can't see the content.
2. Create a deployment project and click on "Configure project"
3. Go to "Release versioning"
4. Click on "Add variable to version"
5. Choose "testpassword" variable.

You can see the contents (i.e. password in plaintext) of the variable in the variables browser and also in the preview of release versions.

This also affects plan variables (not only global variables).

Cheers!
Greg
fields.summary: Passwords from variables are visible in plaintext in release versioning preview

fields.description:
affects version: 5.0 build 3715 - 11 Jul 13

This build: https://extranet-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/CRUCHG-DEFAULT-1065/commit

triggered all 57 branch builds for that plan to run.

Course of action was:

# Added a new shared FECRU-uploader repo to the plan

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Renaming capability label will break task that are configured to use the old label name

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new Executable Command
# Set a Command task to use this executable
# Rename this Executable capability at {{Administration >> Build Resources >> Executable}}
# Run the build in Step 2

h3. Expected Results
The build will run successfully

h3. Actual Results
The build failed with the following exception in the build or remote agent log atlassian-bamboo.log file:
{noformat}
2015-09-18 15:47:51,325 ERROR [0-BAM::data054.vm.cfm.fr::Agent:pool-3-thread-1] [TaskExecutorImpl] Error occurred while running Task 'Install package(3)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.scripttask:task.builder.command.
com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskException: Failed to execute task
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.shell.task.AbstractShellBuildTask.execute(AbstractShellBuildTask.java:84)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.shell.task.AbstractShellBuildTask.execute(AbstractShellBuildTask.java:48)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl$3.call(TaskExecutorImpl.java:281)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl$3.call(TaskExecutorImpl.java:278)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.executeTaskWithPrePostActions(TaskExecutorImpl.java:198)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.executeTasks(TaskExecutorImpl.java:278)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskExecutorImpl.execute(TaskExecutorImpl.java:105)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.build.pipeline.tasks.ExecuteBuildTask.call(ExecuteBuildTask.java:75)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.DefaultBuildAgent.build(DefaultBuildAgent.java:188)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl.waitAndPerformBuild(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:112)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.DefaultBuildAgent$1.run(DefaultBuildAgent.java:110)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.utils.BambooRunnables$1.run(BambooRunnables.java:49)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWith(ImpersonationHelper.java:31)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper.runWithSystemAuthority(ImpersonationHelper.java:20)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:52)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Unknown Source)
Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at java.util.regex.Matcher.getTextLength(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.regex.Matcher.reset(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.regex.Matcher.<init>(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.regex.Pattern.matcher(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.BambooStringUtils$3.apply(BambooStringUtils.java:516)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.util.BambooStringUtils$3.apply(BambooStringUtils.java:509)
	at com.google.common.collect.Lists$TransformingRandomAccessList.get(Lists.java:451)
	at java.util.AbstractList$Itr.next(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.AbstractCollection.toArray(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.LinkedList.addAll(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.LinkedList.addAll(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.process.ExternalProcessBuilder.command(ExternalProcessBuilder.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.process.ProcessServiceImpl.createExternalProcess(ProcessServiceImpl.java:167)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.process.ProcessServiceImpl.executeExternalProcess(ProcessServiceImpl.java:209)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.shell.task.AbstractShellBuildTask.execute(AbstractShellBuildTask.java:61)
{noformat}

The following error is also thrown when tasks are still trying to use the previous capability name.
{code}
2017-05-23 10:41:21,861 ERROR [16-BAM::Local Shared Agent 1::Agent:pool-31-thread-1] [TaskExecutorImpl] Error occurred while running Task 'build ' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.maven:task.builder.mvn3.
java.lang.NullPointerException: Path is not defined for [system.builder.mvn3.Maven]
{code}

Problem has also presented as follows in the build log for NAnt tasks:
{noformat}
error	22-Dec-2016 11:44:28	Error occurred while running Task '(2)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.dotnet:nant.
error	22-Dec-2016 11:44:28	java.lang.NullPointerException: Capability
error	22-Dec-2016 11:44:28		at com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkNotNull(Preconditions.java:226)
error	22-Dec-2016 11:44:28		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugin.dotnet.nant.NantTaskType.getExecutableFile(NantTaskType.java:152)
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
Task configurations treat that label as a key and fail after rename.

h3.Workaround
# Try to re-save the task configuration with the correct executable selected, if this doesn't work then:
# Delete and re-create the task configuration

or
# Search for the Build Plan Task that is using the old name with the following SQL query:
{code:sql}
select b.FULL_KEY from BUILD_DEFINITION bd JOIN BUILD b ON bd.BUILD_ID=b.BUILD_ID WHERE XML_DEFINITION_DATA LIKE '%<old_label>%';
{code}
FULL_KEY is <project_key>- <plan_key>-<job_key>
# Access the configuration of this plan with the URL http://<bamboo.url>:<port>/<context>/build/admin/edit/editBuildTasks.action?buildKey=<FULL_KEY>
# Edit the Task to set it to use the new label
# Save the setting
# For Development Task, use the following SQL query:
{code:sql}
select dp.NAME,de.NAME from DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT de JOIN deployment_project dp ON dp.DEPLOYMENT_PROJECT_ID=de.PACKAGE_DEFINITION_ID WHERE de.XML_DEFINITION_DATA LIKE '%<old_label>%';
{code}
fields.summary: Renaming a capability breaks task configurations

fields.description:
Thank you for improving the artifact download task for BAM-13584 , and here I would like to propose a feature going a step forward based on that.

First I would like to refer to the following branching model in the attachment: [A successful Git branching model|http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/]
!branching_model.png!

Above is the approach my company adopts. I'll give one example to illustrate the issue in the following scenario of Bamboo build.

There are 2 solutions, A and B.  
Solution B requires the dll from A to build. 
Solution A has 3 branches in the repository: Release, Develop, Hotfix1
Solution B has 5 branches in the repository: Release, Develop, Hotfix1, Hotfix2, Feature1

We create 2 Bamboo plans, Plan A and Plan B. We make Plan B to download artifact from Plan A. There are 3 building scenarios:

1. While building Plan B (Release), Plan B would download the artifact of Plan A (Release) and all these would work well in Bamboo 5.1.1. And Plan A (Develop) and Plan A (Hotfix1) are built in the same way.

2. While building Plan B (Feature1), Bamboo would download the artifact of Plan A (Develop). Because repo A does not have a Feature1 branch, according to the branching model, it should use the Develop branch. Bamboo does not support this at the moment.

3. While Building Plan B (Hotfix2), Bamboo would download the artifact of Plan A (Release). The reason is the same as number 2 except that a Hotfix branch is related to Release branch whereas a Feature branch is related to a Develop branch. Bamboo does not support this at the moment.

The number 2 and number 3 are the features that I hope Bamboo would implement. And I believe that is a well structured mapping to a real-world repository branching strategy.
fields.summary: Enable Artifact Downloader to download artifacts from the same branch if existed; download from a specific branch if the same branch plan not existed

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*

1. Enable manual Clover integration, generate HTML and XML report.
2. Define Clover artefact named "Clover Report" (do not use the default "Clover Report (System)" name). - this will force Bamboo Clover Plugin to search through existing artefacts (checking is some specific file exists in any of them) in order to find the report.
3. Run the build. Open Job summary. The Artifacts tab contains "Clover Report" and it shows the content. But the Clover tab does not show it. 

*Reason:*

The FileSystemArtifactLinkDataProvider.exists() does not resolve artefact path correctly. It does not strip prefix from the artifact URL and tries to append the whole URL as a path to a file. Example:

{noformat}
// for one artefact like:
artifactLink.getUrl() = BASE_URL/browse/BSP-CHA-12/artifact/JOB1/Clover-Report/index.html
artifactLink.getLabel() = Clover Report

// ArtifactLinkDataProvider returns URLs:
artifactPath = artifactLinkDataProvider.getUrls() 
     BASE_URL/browse/BSP-CHA-12/artifact/JOB1/Clover-Report/index.html

// if you try to call exists() method on it to check some file in an artefact
artifactLinkDataProvider.exists(artifactPath, "img", "clover.ico")

// the underlying FileSystemArtifactLinkDataProvider will concatenate 
// "file + URL + path components" resulting in stuff like:

D:\Data\bamboo-5.1.1-home\artifacts\BSP-CHA\JOB1\build-00012\Clover-Report\index.html
\BASE_URL\browse\BSP-CHA-12\artifact\JOB1\Clover-Report\index.html
\img\clover.ico
{noformat}

*Suggested fix:*

FileSystemArtifactLinkDataProvider.exists() should recognize path prefix (till the JOB key) and skip it

or 

FileSystemArtifactLinkDataProvider.exists() should take artifactRoot instead of artifact file
fields.summary: Artifact URLs are not properly resolved to the file path

fields.description:
h4. Problem Description
If you have a deployment, before you deploy to your environment you need to create a release in Bamboo. In order to create release you need to create how the version of the release should be configured through _Release Versioning_. When you configure this, there will be a checkbox called _Last number in version_. By default, if you uncheck this option, the version number will not be incremented. This option is usually used if the version has variable that will be incremented automatically such as Build Number. If you uncheck this option and go with creating release the version number will still be incremented.

h4. How to replicate
# Create a Deployment project.
# On _Release Versioning_ make the configuration similar like the following.
!release-deployment_new.png!
# When you _Create Release_ you will notice something wrong. If you configure like previous step, you will get something like the following.
!create-release.png!
# After you've done that, and you create the release, you will notice that the version will be incremented when it should not be.
!list-release.png!
fields.summary: "Last number in version" checkbox in "Release versioning" didn't work correctly

fields.description:
Full 218 line stacktrace can be found at https://paste.atlassian.com/view/12677

On Bamboo startup in OnDemand, this AccessDeniedException is thrown and logged on a freshly provisioned instance.

If this exception is not exceptional, it would be beneficial to not print it at all. Keeping stacktraces reserved for exceptional circumstances makes it easier to spot if there is an actual issue on application start, without having to mentally sift through known benign stacktraces for each application. It also prevents us from logging half a million unhelpful log lines across OnDemand every five minutes.
fields.summary: Benign org.acegisecurity.AccessDeniedException clutter Bamboo logs

fields.description:
Hi, 

We have an automated backup schedule for bamboo that starts every Saturday at midnight. However, it is still not done today (Monday at 10:40 AM). 

The logs don't show any backup activity. I have the JavaMelody monitor plugin attached to bamboo and it shows there is a BambooAutoBackup thread running. 

Attaching server log, JavaMelody screenshot and thread dumps to help with the issue.
